snippet.textDisplay:
Is Terminal Decree really underrated? I played as that clan and felt like a puppet master. I can make any enemy, even the toughest one, wipe out everyone. You can combine mass manipulation with terminal decree to eliminate a dozen or more instantly. Or combine it with any Affect ability.

I haven‚Äôt played the other clans yet, but the Ventrue seems to be the best for crowd control. Tremere are a close 2nd in this regard. Once the tough enemies appear, possession has them solo their own while you wait or pick off stragglers.
snippet.textOriginal:

I haven‚Äôt played the other clans yet, but the Ventrue seems to be the best for crowd control. Tremere are a close 2nd in this regard. Once the tough enemies appear, possession has them solo their own while you wait or pick off stragglers.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a really weaksauce video - you don't go into anything about most of the abilities.

Like, if you feed on an enemy with cauldron of blood you'll take damage over time - BUT you'll also regen your abilities.
so you can trade HP for blood pips.

snippet.textDisplay: something to keep in mind that wasn't mentioned is that your starting clan has affinity's with certain skill categorizes decreasing their skill point cost. so while terminal decree for him cost 5, for me it cost 10. affinity will play a high role into how you build your character, and what skills are actually worthwhile.
snippet.textOriginal: something to keep in mind that wasn't mentioned is that your starting clan has affinity's with certain skill categorizes decreasing their skill point cost. so while terminal decree for him cost 5, for me it cost 10. affinity will play a high role into how you build your character, and what skills are actually worthwhile.

snippet.textDisplay: I grabbed taunt because it's the only way I know how to disarm someone in combat.
snippet.textOriginal: I grabbed taunt because it's the only way I know how to disarm someone in combat.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well, the author of the video didn't mention the coolest ability. 
It's a passive ability of the Toreadors.
It gradually recharges movement abilities. Why is it so good, you may ask?
The thing is, the Ventrue's mind-shifting ability also falls under the category of movement abilities. 
This allows you to wear down your opponents without distracting yourself with feeding, forcing them to fight each other while the vampire watches from the sidelines. And then again and again and again, until there is only one survivor left, barely standing, who can be finished off or eaten.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved playing Tremere in a VTMB. 
And im also enjoying it in VTMB2. Curse someone and then hit them with a telekinesis object to make them explode. 
Killing at a distance with blood daggers. 
Teleporting and destroying the person on the teleport spot.

But at the end of the day its all about play style. Each person has their preferences.

snippet.textDisplay:
The Resonance inducing abilities actually turn a completely non-resonant victim into full blown resonance. Anyone can be turned into a 100 pointer, well as far as civvies go. Enemies just get to become a 20+ resonance. Also, Taunt is very useful in combat. Aim at an annoying elite enemy with a pain in the arse gun, and not only does he drop the gun, he takes more damage from everything incl the gun you just made him drop... which you then can use to drop him.

If you play on PC, there is already mods for the game over at Nexus. A slight cheat I use is gaining double blood pips from feeding, which in my opinion makes things more fun... at least as far as random encounters go. Does not help much in boss fights as far as I've noticed.
snippet.textOriginal:
The Resonance inducing abilities actually turn a completely non-resonant victim into full blown resonance. Anyone can be turned into a 100 pointer, well as far as civvies go. Enemies just get to become a 20+ resonance. Also, Taunt is very useful in combat. Aim at an annoying elite enemy with a pain in the arse gun, and not only does he drop the gun, he takes more damage from everything incl the gun you just made him drop... which you then can use to drop him.

If you play on PC, there is already mods for the game over at Nexus. A slight cheat I use is gaining double blood pips from feeding, which in my opinion makes things more fun... at least as far as random encounters go. Does not help much in boss fights as far as I've noticed.

snippet.textDisplay: Hi for the Tremere players you can "melee" at range you dont need to be in face to face range! Combine that with telekenisis, and also use dash to move back and then melee at range, you can use telekenisis to grab enemies as well so when they stagger grab n feed.

snippet.textDisplay: Tremere costs are (Sanguine/Choleric/Melancholic) Blood Curse (100/50/0), Recall (250/100/0), Cauldron of Blood (400/0/150), Blood Salvo (650/0/300). And yes, that means you need 1400 Sanguine Blood total to unlock all of their abilities, Tremere are definitely the Horny ones for sure. I am surprised you didn't at least talk about the perks being so OP. Toreador's passive lets you recharge a blood pip on your blink or recall or in my case shadow step once every 10 seconds. That's just huge. I don't think taunt and beckon are all that important though, I didn't have any trouble getting the proper reaction out of NPC's just by talking with them when they were fleeting. I guess those abilities just let you wear whatever you want while you do it, but dress rich and you don't have to change at all.
snippet.textOriginal: Tremere costs are (Sanguine/Choleric/Melancholic) Blood Curse (100/50/0), Recall (250/100/0), Cauldron of Blood (400/0/150), Blood Salvo (650/0/300). And yes, that means you need 1400 Sanguine Blood total to unlock all of their abilities, Tremere are definitely the Horny ones for sure. I am surprised you didn't at least talk about the perks being so OP. Toreador's passive lets you recharge a blood pip on your blink or recall or in my case shadow step once every 10 seconds. That's just huge. I don't think taunt and beckon are all that important though, I didn't have any trouble getting the proper reaction out of NPC's just by talking with them when they were fleeting. I guess those abilities just let you wear whatever you want while you do it, but dress rich and you don't have to change at all.

snippet.textDisplay:
Im making a decent speed/melee focused build...im using passive cats grace(toreador clan), lightning strikes and split second. working on getting blurred momentum then cloud memory to replace beckon....this build is based off of vamps from VD/Originals and true blood with speed being a huge part of their combat moveset and some like cloud memory and split second can really help with not just combat but with not breacking the masquerade as much allowing you to get out of situations fast and easy if used right

its been feeling really fun so far so can't wait to get the other two abilities to finish the VD/Originals and true blood build im trying to make üòé
